abstracts.cdata!:
The broader policy objective of the
            Programmatic Bank and Corporate Restructuring Program
            Adjustment Loan/Credit is to support the Government's
            Bank and Corporate Restructuring Program (BCRP), aimed at
            strengthening the financial and corporate sectors, lowering
            systemic risks, and reducing the probability o f crises.
            This will provide an enabling environment to restart prudent
            lending, ultimately boosting economic growth. The
            Bank/Association's (hereinafter called the Bank)
            strategy for Bolivia's financial and corporate sectors
            calls for operations in a programmatic context, each
            focusing on distinct policy measures and actions that, taken
            as a whole, would contribute to the strengthening of the
            financial and corporate sectors and support the
            Government's BCRP. The Government's program,
            supported by this operation, involves seven main components:
            (a) organizational arrangements to manage systemic bank and
            corporate restructuring, (b) legal clarity on appropriate
            distribution of  regulatory powers, (c) bank and corporate
            diagnosis; (d) prudential strengthening and prompt
            corrective action for banks; (d) bank resolution framework;
            (e) legal and institutional framework for corporate
            restructuring; and (f) anti-money laundering. Such
            comprehensive and cohesive program is essential to realign
            incentives and set in motion a process where: (i) viable
            banks participate in the restructuring of troubled but
            viable corporations that make the needed efforts to restore
            their financial health, (ii) troubled but viable banks
            restructure and regain medium-term profitability, and (iii)
            unviable banks and corporations exit the system in an
            orderly manner. While the first Loan/Credit would have
            conditionality largely based on actions in the banking
            sector, the second loan would follow a similar design, but
            with flexibility to include conditionality on the corporate
            sector if sufficient progress is achieved and/or further
            advances on the banking sector take place. The first
            Loan/Credit would be disbursed in two tranches. Several
            benefits will flow from the project: It will support reforms
            that contribute to the strengthening of the financial and
            corporate sectors, lowering systemic risks and reducing the
            probability of crises in the future; enhancing the
            supervisory, regulatory and prompt corrective environment in
            the banking sector;  consolidating and reducing systemic
            risks in financial markets should further shield from
            crises--increasing competition that could promote broader
            access to financial services, and lowering potential drains
            on the public budget to enable effective use for social
            purposes. Enabling corporate restructuring should produce a
            healthier corporate sector that attracts higher levels of
            capital and enables increased production, a stricter
            anti-money laundering environment could potentially increase
            foreign investment in the financial sector, and  boost
            private sector's confidence in the Government's
            commitment to resolve financial and corporate sector
            weaknesses. The main risks facing the operation arise from:
            macro-financial risks, political and social uncertainty,
            limited implementation capacity, inadequate framework for
            corporate restructuring, and the legal framework.
